TopicTitle: Problem sending multiple probes to specific "contract" orbits from a single launch

Articles.Content:
I've only just signed up to the forums, so forgive me if this is posted in the wrong place.

I recently had two contracts on the go to send probes into two different specific orbits of the mun, so I thought to save time I'd kill two birds with one stone and send them both up in one launch. However when I eventually got them both into the correct orbits only one was registered as being successful ![:mad:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_angry.gif), it seems to be because only one probe core was considered to be in "command", even after I had decoupled them. 

So even though I had a probe in the second specific orbit, the one that had been in command when launched was in the first specific orbit. Maybe I've just been stupid and there's a way to remedy this, if so, I'd love some suggestions! If not I really think it should be programmed in that more than one command module can be launched.
You can definitely send multiple sats up in one launch. Are you 100% sure the orbit for the second is correct, and not orbiting in the wrong direction?
You're right! I just came on to delete this as I was orbiting in the wrong direction, I'm a fool! (and a bit of a kerbal amatuer)

Having said that, now I'm heading in the correct direction, the criteria "launch a new unmanned probe with power and an antenna" is still unfulfilled. It definitely has power and an antenna. Maybe because I returned to the space centre its no longer new?
The "power" requirement is a bit poorly named, it really means "power generation". A battery is not enough, it must have a solar panel or RTG.

It has solar panels, I think I jibbed the game out on the whole "new" criteria. oh well, I'll just send another sat. And thanks for the help!

**Edited <time datetime="2015-02-20T19:31:06Z" title="02/20/2015 07:31  PM" data-short="9 yr">February 20, 2015</time> by Toadric**

Don't forget to actually accept the new contract! I once set a sat up to an orbit, got it perfectly matched, and was ???. Then I noticed that I didn't actually accept that contract, but the orbit showed up in the map window. Maybe unaccepted contract orbits/locations should pulse to let you know they are not accepted yet.

> 
> You're right! I just came on to delete this as I was orbiting in the wrong direction, I'm a fool! (and a bit of a kerbal amatuer)

Don't feel too bad, most of us have done that at one time or another (well... I have anyway ![:blush:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_embarrassed.gif))
